 The Department agrees that the Company’s requested variance satisfies the three requirements.  Minnesota Power’s current multi -year credit agreement resembles traditional short -term debt 
instruments.  Classifying mu lti-year credit agreements as long -term debt could cause credit -rating 
agencies to react unfavorably, thus imposing an excessive burden on the Company and hurting ratepayers.  In addition, classifying multi- year credit agreements as short -term debt would not conflict 
with any standards imposed by law.  Therefore, the Department recommends the Commission continue to vary Minn. R. 7825.1000, subp. 6 (2023) and  allow Minnesota Power to treat borrowing 
under multi -year agreements as short -term debt for approved  capital structure purposes.  
 
E. PENDING ACQUISITION OF ALLETE  
 
On May 6, 2024, ALLETE announced that it had entered into an agreement to be acquired by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) .  On t he 
same day, ALLETE filed a Form 8 -K with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that included 
the Agreement and Plan of Merger  (Merger Agreement)  ALLETE entered into with CPP Investments 
and GIP.
10 
 The Agreement and Plan of Merger contains language  which requires ALLETE (and Minnesota Power) 
to receive the written consent of CPP Investments and GIP prior to undertaking  certain business 
activities  while the acquis ition is pending .  Notably, Section 5.01(b)  of the Merger Agreement places 
certain restr ictions on the Company’s ability to issue debt and equity and make or commit to make 
capital expenditures  in excess of a capital expenditure budget the Company provided privately to the 
CPP Investments and GIP . 
 The Department asked Minnesota Power in an i nformation request whether the acquisition and 
Merger Agreement have any impact on the Company’s financing and capital expenditure plans as described in the Petition.  In its response, the Company did not affirmatively state that its projected capital stru cture as of June 30, 2025 is still applicable but  did state that it expected to remain in 
compliance with the equity ratio contingency range proposed in the Petition, which “allows a 
reasonable variance threshold for unexpected or unknown events at the tim e of filing the Petition.”
11  
Minnesota Power also provided the non -public capital expenditure budget referenced in the Merger 
Agreement, which the Department concludes is reasonably comparable to the budget provided in Exhibit L of the Petition.  Thus, the Department has no concerns  related to the Company’s capital 
expenditure plans in the near -term.  
 While the Department has some minor concerns that the base capital structure projection included in the Petition is no longer applicable, the Department agrees that changes to that proj ection resulting 
from the acquisition can reasonably be dealt in Docket E015/PA -24-198, in which the Commission will 
review the proposed acquisition.

 III. CONCLUSIONS AND  RECOMMENDATIONS  
 The Department concludes Minnesota Power’s Petition is reasonable and r ecommends the 
Commission take the following action:  
 
1. Approve Minnesota Power’s Petition which includes the following:  
• ALLETE’s proposed capital structure, including an equity ratio of 63.05%;  
• An equity ratio contingency range of +/ - 15% of its proposed equity ratio (i.e., 53.59% to 
72.51%);  
• Total consolidated capitalization of $6,535 million, including a proposed contingency 
reserve of $597 million;  
• Approval to issue short -term debt up to 15% of total capitalization;  
• Continuation of the varianc e of Minn. R. 7825.1000, subp. 6 (2023) to allow ALLETE to treat 
borrowing under multi -year credit agreements as short -term debt for approved capital 
structure purposes;  
• Authorization to issue securities, provided ALLETE does not exceed the limits of the 
approved equity ratio, maximum short -term debt ratio, or maximum capitalization for more 
than 60 days, without prior Commission approval; and  
• Approval of ALLETE’s estimated consolidated capital structure and authorization to issue 
securities from the date of issuance of a Commission Order approving the instant petition 
through the latter of (1) May 1, 2025 or (2) the date at which the Commission issues a 
subsequent capital structure order.  
2. Require Minnesota Power to file its next request for approval of its  securities issuance no later 
than March 1, 2025.  
3. Require Minnesota Power to keep the Commission informed in a timely manner of any important developments in its pending acquisition and any rating agency actions.  
4. Clarify the Order in this proceeding does not predetermine the Commission’s decision in any future rate case the Company files.

a
. The Company expects to remain in compliance with the capital structure petition as currently filed.
The Company’s requested 15% equity ratio contingency allows a reasonable variance threshold for
unexpected or unknown events at the time of filing the Petition.
b
. Section 5.01 of the “Agreement and Plan of Merger” defines what actions by the Company require
consent from the counterparties to the agreement during the interim time period between signing
the agreement and closing.   As a result, the agreement does not inhibit the ability of the Company
to issue debt or equity, but instead defines what can and cannot be done without the consent of
the counterparties to the agreement.  This adds an additional layer of governance to the
Company's contemplated debt and equity issuances concurrent with the ALLETE Board of Directors
approval. Additionally, the merger agreement states the Company will use commercially
reasonable efforts to maintain its capital structure as authorized by the Minnesota Public Utilities
Commission and will remain in compliance with the petition as filed.
c
. In the same manner described in response to part B, the “Agreement and Plan of Merger” does
not inhibit the Company making capital expenditures as filed in the capital structure petition.
Certain levels of capital expenditures above what is listed in the "Company Disclosure Letter” (see
part D below) require consent of the counterparties in a similar manner as to how ALLETE currently
requires ALLETE Board approval for such expenditures.
d
. As discussed with Department counsel, attached as DOC IR 06 Attach 1 TS and DOC IR 06 Attach 2
TS are the sections of the Disclosure Schedules related to capital structure and securities issuances.

I. INTRODUCTION  
On May 1, 2024, Otter Tail Power Company (OTP, Otter Tail, or the Company) filed a petition (Petition) 
requesting the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (Commission) approve it s 2024 capital structure.  
Specifically, OTP requested approval of:  
 
• A common equity ratio of 47.2% to 57.7% - derived from a midpoint o f 52.4% plus or minus 
10% of the midpoint (+ or –  5.24 percentage points);  
• A maximum capitalization of $2.183 billion derived from a base of $1.984 billion plus a 10% contingency of $0.199 billion;  
• A continuation of the variance to Minn . R. 7825.1000, subp. 6 (2023) , to allow OTP to treat 
borrowings under the multi -year credit agreements as short -term debt for its approved capital 
structure purposes;  
• A request to issue short- term debt up to 15% of OTP’s total capitalization not to exceed $25 0 
million;  and 
• A request to issue securities, providing OTP does not exceed the approved equity ratio, 
maximum short -term debt ratio, or maximum capitalization for more than 60 days.  
 
On August 29, 2023, the Commission issued an Order approving OTP’s most recent capital structure 
Petition, in Docket No. E017/S -23-185. In its Order, the Commission:
  
 
1. Approved Otter Tail’s 2023 proposed capital structure.  
2. Approved Otter Tail’s 2023 proposed equity contingency plus/minus 10% around its proposed equity ratio.  
3. Approved Otter Tail’s request to issue short -term debt up to 15% of capitalization.  
4. Approved Otter Tail’s total maximum capitalization of $1.958 billion, which includes a base 
capitalization of $1.780 billion and a contingency of $0.178 billion.  
5. Allowed Ott er Tail to issue any securities while the Commission’s Order is in effect that would not 
result in an equity or short -term debt ratio outside the proposed range or a total capitalization 
exceeding its proposed cap for more than 60 days.  
6. Continued to vary Minn. R. 7825.1000, subp. 6 (2023), to allow Otter Tail to treat borrowings 
under its multi -year credit agreement as short -term debt for capital structure purposes.  
7. Allowed the approvals to remain in effect until the Commission issues its next capital stru cture Order.  
8. Required Otter Tail to file its next request for approval of its 2024 securities issuances no later 
than May 1, 2024.  
9. Clarified that the Order in this proceeding does not predetermine the Commission’s decision in 
any future rate case the Compa ny files.  
 

Docket No. E017/S -24-182 
Analyst(s) assigned: Justin Taylor and Craig Addonizio  
Page 2 
 
 
 
 II. DEPARTMENT ANALYSIS  
A. BACKGROUND  
OTP is a Minnesota c orporation with about 63,000 retail electricity customers in Minnesota.1  OTP is a 
wholly owned subsidiary of Otter Tail Corporation, a holding company that also owns manufacturing 
and industrial -products operating companies.  As a wholly owned subsidiary, OTP has its own capital 
structure and issues its own debt but does not is sue equity securities and instead receives equity 
contributions from Otter Tail Corporation.  OTP currently maintains a long -term issuer credit rating of 
BBB+ from Standard & Poor’s (S&P), two levels above the investment -grade minimum of BBB -.  
 
To issue securities, OTP needs approval under Minn.  Stat. § 216B.49 (2023)  and approval of its capital 
structure per Minn.  R. 7825.1100 (2023) .  OTP submitted a petition requesting both authorizations to 
issue securities and approval of its 2023 capital structure.  The Company’s 2023 capital structure is 
effective until the Commission issues its Order regarding OTP’s 2024 capital structure.  
 
B. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS  
Minn.  R. 7825.1300 and 7825.1400 (2023) and prior Commission Orders set forth a number of 
reporting requirements utilities must adhere to for the issuance of securities.   The Department 
reviewed OTP’s Petition and concludes the Company meets all applicable  requirements . 
 C. REASONABLENESS OF OTP’S PROPOSED CAPITAL STRUCTURE AND CONTINGENCY RANGES

 2. General Discussion  of Capital Structure Theory  
The mix of debt and equity a company uses to finance its operations impacts the cost of its debt and 
equity.  Generally, interest payments on debt are tax deductible, and therefore , all else equal,  the use 
of debt financing creates tax savings , which lowers costs for ratepayers.  However, the use of debt 
(leverage)  also creates fixed payment obligations ( i.e., interest and principal payments), for which a 
failure to pay could trigger a costly bankruptcy.  Debt and equity investors are aware of the risks 
associated with high levels of debt, and as a result, require higher expected returns on their investments as leverage increases.   
 
A company must appropriately balance these two competing factors (tax savings and increased costs due to higher financial risk) in determining its capital structure.  Starting from a low level of debt, the 
tax savings generated by increasing the amount of debt in a company’s capital structure often more 
than offsets the increase in the cost of debt and equity resulting from increased financial risk. Past a certain point, however, the increase in the costs of debt and equity will outweigh the additional tax savings.  
 
Theoretically, every company has a n optimal capital structure that balances these two effects and 
minimizes the company’s cost of capital, after accounting for taxes .  Figure 1 illustrates this 
relationship.  As shown, both debt equity costs increase with leverage, but “Total Capital Cost” (the weighted average cost of capital adjusted to reflect tax savings associated with debt) decreases as debt 
increases up to 50%, and then begins to rise as the effects of financial ri sk begin to outweigh the tax 
savings associated with increased leverage.

While an optimal capital structure theoretically  exists for each company, as a practical matter, it is 
difficult, if not impossible, to analytically determine what that capital structure is with any precision.  
Because of this, historically, the Department has  typically  assessed the reasonableness of utilities’ capital 
structures by simply comparing them to the capital structures of other utilities of comparable risk.   
 
That simple comparison  test, however, is  a somewhat blunt too l.  The range of capital structures used 
by other utilities is often so wide that it provides little insight into the reasonableness of a particular capital structure.  In addition, there is often disagreement between the Department and the utilities about how to apply the test.  Specifically, the Department generally compares a utility’s proposed capital structure only t o publicly traded companies that are primarily comprised of utility operations.  
The utilities, however, often compare their proposed capital structure to the capital structures of  other  
utility operating subsidiaries, which are not publicly traded.  As th e Department has discussed in recent 
rate cases, the utilities ’ comparisons create a problematic mismatch between (a) the proxy companies 
used to assess a utility’s proposed capital structure ( i.e., utility operating subsidiaries) and (b) the proxy 
companies used to estimate a utility’s cost of equity ( i.e., publicly traded parent or holding 
companies).
4  In short, publicly traded parent companies often have higher debt ratios than their utility 
operating subsidiaries, which implies that they also likely h ave higher costs of equity.  
 However, i n the absence of a better, more precise method of assessing capital structure , the 
Department used the comparison test to assess OTP’s proposed capital structure, as discussed in greater detail below.  
 
3. Reasonableness of OTP’s Proposed Capital Structure  
In its Petition, OTP requested approval of a 52.4% common equity ratio and an equity ratio contingency range of 47.2% to 57.7%.
5  The contingency range equates to plus/minus 5.24% (or 10% of 
OTP’s common equity ratio).  OTP also requested the ability to exceed the approved range for up to 60 
days without prior Commission approval.  OTP’s proposed equity ratio and contingency range are 
slightly lower than the Company’s currently -approved parameters of 53.7% and contingenc y range of 
48.3% - 59.1%.6 
 
OTP’s Petition included no support or analysis demonstrating that its proposed capital structure is reasonable , or that a higher or lower e quity ratio would not result in a lower long -run weighted 
average cost of capital (including tax effects).  In its response to Department Information Request No. 1, the Company stated that “periodically assesses this issue in the broader context of minimizing overall cost of capital while maintaining reasonable equity ratios to support our credit ratings and 
attract capital” but was unable to identify or provide any related analyses it has conducted from the

 last five years.7  The Company also discussed its attempts to minimize its cost of debt, but as discussed 
above, minimizing the cost of debt does not equate to minimizing the after -tax weighted average cost 
of capital.  
 
The Department compared the Company’s proposed capita l structure to the actual capital structures 
of other, risk -comparable electric utilities.  32 publicly traded companies classified by Value Line as 
electric utilities have S&P credit ratings between A and BBB -, two notches above and below OTP’s 
credit rat ing of BBB+.  At the end of 2023, the equity ratios of those 32 companies range from 27.9% to 
62.2% and  averaged 41.0%.8   The Department notes while OTP’s proposed equity ratio is within the  
range  of other electric utilities’ , it is significantly above average.  Of the 32  electric utilities in the 
Department’s comparison group, only two have a common equity ratio higher than OTP’s proposed 
equity ratio .  While OTP’s capital structure may raise some concerns that the Company’s equity ratio is 
higher than o ptimal, it does not raise concerns about an equity ratio that is too low, potentially having 
negative effects on the Company between rate cases, the primary concern for annual capital structure dockets.   For this reason, the Department concludes that OTP’s  proposed capital structure is 
reasonable and recommends that the Commission approve it.  
 
4. Reasonableness of OTP’s Proposed Contingency Ranges  
a. Equity Ratio Contingency Range  
Historically, the Commission has authorized OTP to use a 10% range around the commo n-equity 
midpoint and a 60 -day grace period, including the 2023 capital structure currently in effect.  Given this 
history and the lack of adverse outcomes in recent years, the Department believes this practice has worked well enough to allow the Company s ufficient financing flexibility, to keep the Company on 
sound financial footing, and to maintain needed oversight for the Commission.  The Department therefore concludes continued adoption of this practice is reasonable.  
 Based on the above, the Department  concludes that OTP’s proposed equity ratio contingency range of 
47.2% to 57.7% is  reasonable and recommends that the Commission approve it . 
 
b. Short -Term Debt Ratio  Contingency Range  
OTP requested permission to issue up to 15% of the Company’s total capital ization as short -term debt.  
In recent years, the Commission has approved the 15% cap on OTP’s short -term debt.  Similar to the 
equity ratio contingency range, the Department concludes that this practice has worked well enough 
to provide OTP adequate short- term financial flexibility without adding undue risk to ratepayers.  
Therefore, the Department recommends the Commission approve OTP’s request to issue 15% of the 
Company’s total capitalization.

 c. Maximum Total Capitalization  
OTP requested a maximum capitalization of $2.182 billion derived from a base of $1.984 billion plus a 
10% contingency of $0.198 billion.9  The requested maximum is 11.44% higher than the $1.958 billion 
approved in OTP’s 2023 capital structure Petition.10  According to Otter Tail, the additional 
capitalization is required to fund the company’s projected capital expenditures, which relate pri marily 
to its planned transmission, solar and wind investments.11  The 10% contingency for total capitalization 
is consistent with past practice, and the Department concludes that this practice has worked 
sufficiently well to balance financial flexibility for the utility with adequate oversight for the 
Commission.  Therefore, the Department recommends that the Commission approve OTP’s proposed maximum total capitalization.  
 
D. VARIANCE OF MINN . R. 7825.1000, SUBP.  6 (2023)  
OTP requested the Commission continue  to vary Minn . R. 7825.1000, subp . 6 (2023) , to allow OTP to 
treat borrowing under its multi -year credit agreement as short -term debt for approved capital 
structure purposes.  Because Minn.  R. 7825.1000, subp . 6 (2023) , defines short -term securities as tho se 
with a date of maturity of no more than one year, to classify multi -year credit agreements as short -
term debt, OTP needs the Commission to approve the requested variance.  To vary its rules, the 
Commission must determine, per Minn.  R. 7829.3200, subp . 1 (2023) , the variance satisfies three 
requirements:   
 
A. Enforcement of the rule would impose an excessive burden upon the applicant or others affected by the rule;  
B. Granting the variance would not adversely affect the public interest; and  
C. Granting the variance would not conflict with standards imposed by law.  
 The Department agrees with OTP that the Company’s requested variance satisfies the three requirements.  OTP’s current multi -year credit agreement resembles traditional short -term debt 
instruments.   Classifying multi -year credit agreements as long -term debt could cause credit -rating 
agencies to react unfavorably, thus imposing an excessive burden on OTP and hurting ratepayers.  In 
addition, classifying multi- year credit agreements as short -term debt  would not conflict with any 
standards imposed by law.  Therefore, the Department recommends the Commission continue to vary 
Minn.  R. 7825.1000, subp . 6 (2023) , and allow OTP to treat borrowing under multi- year agreements as 
short -term debt for approved ca pital structure purposes.  
 
E. OTP’S SECURITY ISSUANCE  
OTP requested the Commission allow the Company to issue debt securities and receive equity contributions from Otter Tail Corporation, as long as the Company stays within the approved capital structure.

 Minn. Stat.  § 216B.49, subd . 3 (2023) , states a securities issuance by a public utility may be authorized 
by the Commission individually, or as one of multiple possible issuances approved in the course of a 
periodic capital structure proceeding.  In OTP’s Petition, the Company requested authorization to issue 
several types of securities including long -term debt, inter -company notes, short- term debt.  OTP’s 
common equity is received from its parent company.    
 
Pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 216B.49, subd . 4, no public utility may issue a security without a prior finding 
by the Commission that 1) the amount of securities of each class bears a reasonable proportion to each 
other and to the value of the property considering the nature of the business of the public utility, its credit and prospects, the possibility  that the value of  the property may chang e, the effect which the 
issuance  will have on the utility’s management and operations , and any other matter the Commission 
deems relevant ; and 2) the issuance is reasonable and proper, in the public interest, and will not be 
detrimental to affected consume rs.   
 Based on the analysis above, the Department concludes that any securities issuances  the Company 
makes that result in a capital structure with debt and equity ratios within the contingency ranges 
described above  will satisfy the requirem ent that amounts of each class of securities bear a reasonable 
proportion to e ach other.  Consistent with the Commission’s May 12, 2009 Order in Docket No. 
E,G999/CI -08-1416, the Company included in its Petition a general projection of its capital needs  for its 
ordinary operat ions.  The total capitalization limit proposed in the Petition is reasonably consistent 
with the projected need, and therefore the Department concludes that securities issuances that result in a capital structure within the total capitalization lim it are reasonably likely to not be detrimental to 
ratepayers.  Fu rther, any rate increases stemming from expenditures funded with new securities 
issuances will be su bject to a prudence review in a future rate proceeding.   
 The Department does not take a position in this filing as to whether OTP’s request complies with additional requirements of law, including Minnesota Statutes Chapter 80A. Therefore, the Department recommends the Commission approve OTP’s request to issue se curities within the parameters of the 
approved capital structure , as well as other applicable securities laws . 
 
III. CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS  
The Department concludes OTP’s proposed capital structure Petition is reasonable and recommends the Commission t ake the following action:  
 
1. Approve Otter Tail Power Company’s 2024 proposed capital structure;  
2. Approve Otter Tail Power Company’s proposed equity contingency of plus/minus 10% around its 2024 common equity ratio;  
3. Approve Otter Tail Power Company’s request to issue short- term debt up to 15% of 
capitalization;  
4. Approve Otter Tail Power Company’s total maximum capitalization of $2.183 billion which includes a base capitalization of $1.984 billion and a contingency of $0.19 8 billion;

Given the scope of OTP’s capital expenditure plan, OTP has determined it is prudent to 
strengthen its balance sheet to support its investment plans and help maintain strong 
senior unsecured credit ratings. Thus, OTP’s equity ratio has increased over time through 
a mixture of retained earnings and equity infusions from Otter Tail Corporation. OTP’s 
equity ratio is projected to remain at 2024 levels.  
OTP must be able to access capital at a reasonable cost to finance both investments and 
operations. Further, this access must occur in a variety of economic conditions. Recent 
events, including the COVID -19 pandemic, Winter Storms Uri and Elliott, and bank 
failures in 2023 all severely impacted different aspects of the financial system. 
Additionally, different structural changes like sustained higher energy prices, greater 
sales volatility, supply chain challenges and inflation affect the conditions under which 
OTP is able to access the financial markets. By strengthening OTP’s balance sheet, the 
company is able to better meet those changes and continue to maintain access to capital at 
reasonable costs.  
Attachment 1 to MN -DOC -001 is a copy of Schedule 15 Ann E. Bulkley submitted with 
direct testimony on November 2, 2023 in Otter Tail Power’s rate case in North Dakota. In 
that attachment, Ms. Bulkley calculated the average proportion of common equity, long -
term debt, preferred equity and short -term debt for the most recent eight quarters for each 
of the companies in the proxy group at the operating subsidiary level. The average 
common equity ratio for the operating subsidiaries of the proxy group companies was 
52.06 percent (within a range from 45.30 percent to 60.41 percent). Given that OTP’s 
proposed equity ratio (13 -month average) of 53.50 percent is well within the range of 
equity ratios for the utility operating subsidiaries of the proxy group companies, Otter 
Tail Power considers its proposed equity ratio to be reasonable.  
B.As noted above, the company considers minimizing the cost of capital and the
strengthening of the balance sheet is a way to keep the long and short -term debt borrow
costs down by maintaining ratings with Moody’s and S&P and Fitch which assist in
lower borrowing costs on debt issuances. Additionally, OTP works with lenders to
achieve the lowest interest rates possible when issuing debt to provide the lowest cost of
borrowing which ultimately helps minimize the weighted average cost of capital.
OTP issues LTD securities in private placements to institutional investors. OTP has not 
issued public LTD.  To help keep interest rates low, OTP’s LTD offerings have been 
through private placements with institutional investors because the amounts placed by 
OTP at any single time are too small for an economic public issuance.  
Regarding the question of whether the Company considers the objective of minimizing its 
current market after -tax weighted average cost of capital in determining its 
target/proposed capital structure and what analysis the Company may have done in this 
regard; the Company periodically assesses this issue in the broader context of minimizing 
overall cost of capital while maintaining reasonable equity ratios to support our credit 
ratings and attract capital.     We have not identified any written analysis responsive to the 
specific point of this Information Request.

I. INTRODUCTION   
On October 31 , 202 4, Northern States Power Company, doing business as Xcel Energy (Xcel Energy or 
the Company ), filed a petition (Petition) seeking approval from the Minnesota Public Utilities  
Commission (Commission) for the Company’s proposed 202 5 capital structure, as well as permission to  
issue securities within the scope of the proposed capital structure, plus contingencies. Specifically, the  
Company is seeking:  
 
• Total capitalization of $ 20.0  billion, including a contingency of $7 71 million;  
• A consolidated equity ratio of 52. 40 percent with a contingency range of ±10 percent (i.e., a 
range of 47. 16 percent to 5 7.64  percent);  
• The ability to issue short- term debt not to exceed 15 percent of total capitalization;  
• Continuation of the variance permitting it to enter into and use multi -year credit  agreements 
and issue associated notes, and to consider any direct borrowings as short -term  debt for 
approved capital structure purposes;  
• Flexibility to issue securities provided that the Company remains within the contingency  ranges 
or does not exceed them for more than 60 days without Commission  authorization;  
• Continued flexibility to issue long -term debt, provided the Company remains within the  limits 
approved for the short -term debt and equity ratios, as well as within the total capitalization 
limit;  
• Flexibility to use risk management instruments that qualify for hedge accounting  treatment;  
• Approval to have discretion to enter into financings to replace outstanding long -term  debt 
instruments with less expensive securities after considering the debt issuance  expenses and 
amortization of redemption premiums and expenses, and to enter into  tax-exempt financings if 
funds are available for construction programs; and,  
• Approval of the 202 5 capital structure by February 1, 202 5, effective until the  Commission 
issues a 202 6 capital structure Order.  
 
Table 1 summarizes Xcel Energy’s actual capital structure as of June 30, 202 4, its proposed capital  
structure on December 31, 202 5, and the differences between the two.

As shown, the Company’s proposal reflects an increase in total capitalization of $2. 4 billion, or  
approximately 1 4 percent, over the 18 months ending December 31, 202 5, and small changes in its

new capital, with the most significant investments being made in new electric  distribution and 
transmission assets, and new wind and solar facilities . 
II. PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND   
  
October  31, 202 4 Northern States Power Company, doing business as Xcel Energy,  filed a 
petition requesting approval of its 2025 Capital Structure.  
  
III. DEPARTMENT ANALYSIS  
A. REPORTING AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS  
Minnesota Rules 7825.1000 – 7825.1500 and several prior Commission orders establish a number of  
reporting requirements relevant to Xcel Energy’s capital structure filings. In addition, the Commission  
has imposed in various orders other ongoing requirements with which the Company must comply, such  
as restrictions on its use of the Utility Money Pool. Department Attachment 1 lists the various  
requirements. The Department has reviewed the Company’s Petition and concludes that the Company  
has complied with all relevant requirements.  
 
 
1 Petition, Attachment B.  
Docket No. E002/ S-24-368 
Analyst(s) assigned: Craig Addonizio and Justin Taylor  
 
 
 
 
3 B. XCEL ENERGY’S PROPOSED CAPITAL STRUCTURE AND REQUEST FOR 
FLEXIBILITY TO ISSUE SECURITIES TO APPROVED CONTINGENCY RANGES  
B.1. Applicable Statutes  
 Minnesota Statues section 216B.49, subdivision 3 states:  
It is unlawful for any public utility organized under the laws of this  state to  
offer or sell any security … unless the security issuance of the public utility  
is first approved by the commission, either as an individual issuance or as one of multiple possible issuances approved in the course of a periodic  
proceeding reviewing the utility's proposed sources and uses of capital  
funds. Approval by the commission must be by formal written order.  
 
Further, Minnesota Statutes section 216B.49, subdivision 4 states, in part:  
If the commission shall find that the proposed security issuance is  
reasonable and proper and in the public interest and will not be  
detrimental to the interests of the consumers and patrons affected  
thereby, the commission shall by written order grant its permission for the  
proposed public financing.  
 
B.2. Reasonableness of Xcel Energy’s Proposed Capital Structure  
 
Finance theory suggests a number of factors that a company might weigh in determining its target 
capital structure. The most important, arguably, is that because interest payments on debt are tax  
deductible, the use of debt in a company’s capital structure creates net cost savings via lower taxes.  
However, debt also creates binding financial obligations in the form of required interest and principal 
payments, which increase the risk of financial distress and potentially bankruptcy. As a company’s  debt 
load grows, investors will be aware of this risk, and past a certain point, the returns both debt and 
equity investors require to compensate for this risk will begin to increase such that they more than offset the tax savings generated from the additional debt. Companies must weigh these competing  
pressures to find a capital structure that strikes a reasonable balance between debt and equity.  
 While finance theory suggests that each firm has an optimal capital structure that minimizes its  after -
tax weighted average cost of capital, it does not offer a clear method of determining what that optimal 
capital structure is. As a result, assessing the reasonableness of Xcel Energy’s proposed capital structure is difficult. Xcel Energy’s Petition did not include any analysis or discussion demonstrating  
that its proposed capital structure is optimal, or at least cannot easily be improved upon.  
 
Docket No. E002/ S-24-368 
Analyst(s) assigned: Craig Addonizio and Justin Taylor  
 
 
 
 
4 One simple method of assessing the Company’s proposed capital structure is to compare it to the  
capital structure of other utilities. As shown in Department Attachment 2, the equity ratios of  
companies classified as electric utilities by the investment research firm Value Line range from 2 7.9 
percent to 6 1.4 percent. Xcel Energy’s proposed equity ratio is within this range, providing some  
support for the Company’s proposed capital structure. However, the wide range of equity ratios among  
electric utilities does not allow for strong assurance that Xcel Energy’s proposed capital structure is 
reasonable. And even given the wide range, Xcel Energy’s proposed equity ratio  of 52. 4 percent is well 
above average (4 1.2 percent), and higher than that of all but three  of the 3 5 utilities listed , which may 
indicate the Company’s equity ratio is higher than optimal.  
 
The Department also notes that Xcel Energy, Inc.’s capital structure contains notably more debt than 
those of its utility subsidiaries, including Northern States Power Minnesota .

It is not clear why it is reasonable for Xcel Energy, Inc.’s to be financed with so much more debt than its utility subsidiaries.  
 
However, f or now, the Department notes  that Xcel Energy’s proposed capital structure is consistent 
with its past practice, and appears to be  reasonable based on a comparison to the capital structures of 
other utilities, which is the standard the  Department has applied historically.

5 B.3. Reasonableness of Proposed Contingencies and Flexibility to Issue Securities 
Subject to those Contingencies  
 
As noted above, Xcel Energy proposed the following contingencies related to its capital structure:  
 
• an equity ratio contingency range of 47. 16 percent to 57.64 percent, or 10  
percent below and above its proposed equity ratio of 52. 40 percent  
• a cap on short -term debt of 15 percent of total capitalization; and  
• a contingency of $7 71 million, or 4. 0 percent for its total capitalization.  
 
The proposed contingency ranges for the Company’s equity ratio, short- term debt ratio, and total  
capitalization are consistent with long -standing practices and appear to successfully be serving the  
purpose of providing the Company with adequate short- term flexibility without subjecting ratepayers  
to undue risk. For that reason, the Department concludes that Xcel Energy’s proposals are reasonable.  
 
The Department notes that while Xcel Energy did not request a specific long -term debt contingency  
range, that contingency would effectively be set by the Company’s other proposals. At the minimum  
allowable equity and short- term debt ratios under Company’s proposal (47. 16 percent and zero,  
respectively), the Company’s long -term debt ratio would be 52. 5 percent. If the Company were to 
reach both that maximum long -term debt ratio and its proposed maximum total capitalization ($ 20.0  
billion), its long -term debt balance would be $ 10.5  billion. This amount is notably higher than its 
current and projected total debt balances of $ 8.0 and $ 9.0 billion, respectively, and the associated 
increase in the Company’s required interest and, eventually, principal payments , would result in 
increased financial risk.  
 
However, the Department understands that Xcel Energy’s goal is to maintain a capital structure 
relatively close to its proposed capital structure (with a 52. 4 percent equity ratio), and the 
contingencies are  intended to allow the Company flexibility to handle unforeseen financing needs. If 
the Company’s capital structure were to deviate from the proposed capital structure significantly, the 
Department expects that the Company would work to return to its prefe rred capital structure, and the 
Commission would continue to have oversight over the Company’s capital structure.  
 Based on the above discussion, the Department concludes that the Company’s proposed contingencies  
are reasonable, and recommends that the Commission approve them. Similarly, the Department  
recommends that the Commission approve the Company’s request for approval to issue securities  
provided that the Company stays within the proposed contingency ranges or does not exceed them for  
more than 60 days without Commission authorization.  
  
Docket No. E002/ S-24-368 
Analyst(s) assigned: Craig Addonizio and Justin Taylor  
 
 
 
 
6 C. CONTINUANCE OF THE VARIANCE FOR THE MULTI -YEAR CREDIT 
AGREEMENT  
Xcel Energy requested a continuing variance from Minn. R. 7825.1000, subp. 6, for authority to treat 
direct borrowings under its multi -year credit facility (MYCF) as short -term debt. The Rule defines  short -
term debt as debt with a maturity of no more than one year from the date of issuance. Because  the 
MYCF is a multi- year agreement, the Company needs the Commission to vary Minn. R. 7825.1000,  
subp. 6 in order to treat borrowings as debt with a maturity of less than one year.  
 
Per Minn. R. 7829.3200, the Commission can only grant a variance if the following three requirements  
are met:  
 
1. enforcement of the rule would impose an excessive burden upon the applicant  
or others affected by the rule;  
2. granting the variance would not adversely affect the public interest; and  
3. granting the variance would not conflict with standards imposed by law.  
 The Department agrees with the Company that these requirements are satisfied. While the MYCF is a  
multi -year agreement, borrowing s under the MYCF are intended to be short- term and therefore  
resemble the type of short- term debt governed by Minn. R. 7825.1000. Credit ratings agencies may  
react unfavorably if borrowings under the MYCF were classified as long -term debt, thus imposing an 
excessive burden on the Company and potentially its ratepayers. Classifying the MYCF as short -term  
debt would not adversely affect the public interest, and the Department is not aware of any standards  
imposed by law with which granting the variance would conflict. Therefore, the Department  
recommends that the Commission grant the requested variance.  
D. PERMISSION TO USE RISK -MANAGEMENT INSTRUMENTS  
Xcel Energy requested continued permission to use risk -management instruments that qualify for 
hedge accounting treatment under Accounting Standards Codification No. 815 (e.g., U.S. Treasury locks and interest rate swaps) in compliance with the policies of  the Company’s parent, Xcel Energy, Inc., and 
with required officer approvals. The Company also stated that it would report on the use of any such 
instruments in its next annual capital structure filing.  
 
In this Petition, the Company reported that in response to interest rate volatility leading up to its 
February 2024  debt issuance, it entered into a  number of 30 -year forward treasury contract rate locks 
to hedge against unfavorable changes in interest rates and provide some certainty regarding the 
proceeds of the issuance. The Company stated  that its hedges resulted in a roughly $ 8.5 million gain 
that it will reflect in its cost of debt.
3 
 
3 Petition, Attachment I -2 at 146.  
Docket No. E002/ S-24-368 
Analyst(s) assigned: Craig Addonizio and Justin Taylor  
 
 
 
 
7 The Department generally agrees that the risk -management instruments Xcel Energy requests 
flexibility to use can benefit ratepayers as long as the Company follows prudent corporate guidelines.  
The Company’s use of these instruments to hedge against changes in interest rates in advance of its 
May 2023 issuance also appears to have been reasonable. Further, the Commission will have continued 
oversight over the Company’s use of these instruments. T herefore, the Department recommends that 
the Commission approve the Company’s request.  
E. PERMISSION TO ENTER INTO CERTAIN OTHER FINANCINGS  
Xcel Energy requested permission to have discretion to enter into financings to replace outstanding long -term debt instruments with less expens ive securities after considering all relevant costs, and to 
enter into tax -exempt financings if funds are available for construction programs. As both types of 
types of financings could reduce costs to ratepayers, the Department recommends that the 
Commissio n approve the Company’s request. The Department also requests that the Company report 
on any such financings in  its next capital structure filing.  
IV. DEPARTMENT RECOMMENDATIONS  
While the Department has some concerns about the lack of analysis in the record regarding alternative  
capital structures with more or less debt, based on its review, and for the reasons discussed above, the 
Department concludes that Xcel Energy’s requests in this proceeding are reasonable. Therefore, the 
Department recommends that the Commission approve Xc el Energy’s Petition  for approval of the 
Company’s 2025 Capital Structure .

Minn. Rules  
7825.1400 A. A descriptive title . 
B. A table of contents.  
C. The exact name of the petitioner and address of its principal business office.  
D. Name, address, and telephone number of the person authorized to receive notices 
and communications with respect to the petition.  
E. A verified statement by a responsible officer of the petitioner attesting to the 
accuracy and  completeness of the enclosed information.  
F. The purpose for which the securities are to be issued.  
G. Copies of resolutions by the directors authorizing the petition for the issue or 
assumption of liability in  respect to which the petition is made; and if approval of 
stockholders has been obtained, copies of the resolution of the stockholders shall be 
furnished.  
H. A statement as to whether, at the time of filing of the petition, the petitioner knows 
of any person  who is an "affiliated interest" within the meaning of Minnesota Statutes, 
section 216B.48, subdivision 1, who has received or is entitled to receive a fee for 
services in connection with the negotiations or  consummation of the issuance of the 
securities, or for services in securing underwriters, sellers, or  purchasers of the 
securities.  
I. A signed copy of the opinion of counsel in respect to the legality of the issue or 
assumption of liability.  
J. A balance sheet dated no earlier than six months prior to the date of the petition 
together with an income statement and statement of changes in financial position 
covering the 12 months then ended. When the petitions include long-term securities, 
such statements shall show the effects of the issuance  on such balance sheet and 
income statement.  
K. A description of the security or securities to be issued.  
L. An estimate of the interest or dividend cost per $100 principal amount, except in the 
case of common  stock, and a description of any anticipated terms or indenture 
provisions.  
M. If the petitioner is a corporation, a copy of its current articles of incorporation 
certified by the secretary of state of incorporation. If the current articles have already 
been filed, the petitioner need only  make specific reference to such filings.  
N(1). The amount and kinds of stock authorized by articles of incorporation and 
amount outstanding.  
N(2). The terms of preference of preferred stock, whether cumulative or participating, 
or on dividends or  assets, or otherwise.  
N(3). A brief description of each security agreement, mortgage, and deed of trust upon 
petitioner's property, showing date of execution, debtor, and secured party, 
mortgagor and mortgagee and trustor  and beneficiary, amount of indebtedness

I. INTRODUCTION  
 The Minnesota Department of Commerce (Department) respectfully submits these 
Supplemental Comments in response  to the comments submitted by the Office of the 
Attorney General Anti -Trust and Utilities Division (OAG -AUD) on April 20 , 2015 and the reply 
comments submitted by Minnesota Energy Resources Corporation (MERC or Applicant) on  
April 27, 2015.   
 In its comments filed on April 20, 2015, the Department recommended that the 
Commission add the following  three conditions  to the list of 30 proposed conditions the 
Department included in Attachment B to its April 20, 2015 filing : 
 
1. The Commission will deny  MERC recovery of increased financing costs due to any 
rating agency downgrades in any subsequent general rate proceeding for the first three years following the merger.  
 
2. Any increased capital costs determined by the Commission to be related to 
downgrading  or other credit degradation of the holding company and/or non -
utility affiliates should be removed from the cost of capital for MERC.  
 
3. Costs allocated or assigned from IBS, or its successor,  cannot increase above the 
level approved in MERC’s most recent g eneral rate case (Docket E -011/GR -13-
617) for rate -making purposes for the first three years after the Proposed 
Transaction is executed.  
 
After reviewing the OAG -AUD’s comments and the Company’s reply comments, the 
Department modifies its recommendation regarding the three conditions listed above , but 
not to the thirty conditions included in Attachment B of its earlier comments . 
  

Docket No. G011/PA-14 -664  
Analyst assigned:  John Kundert  
Page 2  
 
 
 
II. DEPARTMENT ANALYSIS  
 A. OAG-RUD RECOMMENDATIONS  
 
The OAG -AUD included 33 recommendations in its comments.  One recommendation of 
particular interest to the Department is OAG -AUD recommendation #32 which states:  
 
If MERC’s cost of debt increases during the next three calendar years, Minnesota 
ratepayers will be held harmless from any rate impact un less MERC can demonstrate 
that its increase d cost of debt was not caused by the proposed transaction.  
 The Department believes that this recommendation captures the intent of the Department’s 
recommendations #1 and #2 included in its April 20, 2015 comment s.  Consequently, the 
Department supports OAG -AUD recommendation #32 and withdraw s Department 
recommendations #1 and #2 above.     
 
B. MERC REPLY COMMENTS  
 MERC noted in its reply comments that it opposed the Department’s third recommendation.  The Company explained t hat a ny new affiliated interest agreement between MERC and 
Wisconsin Energy Corporation ( WEC ) Business Services will require Commission approval 
and that the Department’s concern regarding service costs could be addressed in that 
future proceedi ng.   MERC also revisited its rationale that the Department and the 
Commission can address this issue in the Company’s upcoming rate case.  
 The Department agrees with MERC’s rationale and respectfully withdraws the third 
recommendation listed in its April 20, 2015 comments .    
  
III. RECOMMENDATIONS  
 The Department recommends that the Commission approve MERC’s petition with the thirty 
conditions listed in Attachment B of its April 20, 2015 comments.  In addition, the 
Department recommends the following condition:  
 
If MERC’s cost of debt increases during the next three calendar years, Minnesota 
ratepayers will be held harmless from any rate impact unless MERC can demonstrate that its increased cost of debt was not caused by the proposed transaction.  
 This condition is identical to one proposed by the OAG -AUD in its April 20, 2015 comments 
as #32.  
 In total, the Department recommends that the Commission approve the petition with the 
thirty -one conditions it has identified.

1. This article relates to S&P Global Ratings' stand-alone credit profiles
(SACPs).
2. SACPs refer to S&P Global Ratings' opinion of an issue's or issuer's
creditworthiness, in the absence of extraordinary intervention from its
parent or affiliate or related government, and are but one component of a
rating. We use lowercase symbols, for example 'aaa', or 'aa', to designate
SACPs, and may modify this symbol with a "+" or "-" sign, depending on
the specificity of the relevant analysis. SACPs do not have outlooks and are
not placed on CreditWatch. We do not consider SACPs to be ratings, in
contrast to SPURs (S&P Global Ratings' underlying ratings), which reflect
an issuer's credit quality without enhancement.
3. We are publishing this article to help market participants better
understand our approach to reviewing the components of ratings when
other entities, including governments and parents, influence credit quality.3/29/25, 7:49 PM S&P Global Ratings

METHODOLOGY
Definition Of Stand-Alone Credit Profile (SACP)
9. The SACP is not a rating, but a component of the issue rating or issuer
credit rating (ICR). We do not assign outlooks to SACPs or place them on
CreditWatch.
10. S&P Global Ratings' may assign an SACP as a component of a rating to
provide information on an issuer's creditworthiness. The SACP is S&P
Global Ratings' opinion of an issuer's creditworthiness in the absence ofPrinciples Of Credit Ratings3/29/25, 7:49 PM S&P Global Ratings
https://disclosure.spglobal.com/ratings/en/regulatory/article/-/view/sourceId/6219375 2/13
extraordinary support or burden. It incorporates direct support already
committed and the influence of ongoing interactions with the issuer's
group and/or government. However, the SACP differs from the ICR in that it
does not include potential future extraordinary support from a group or
government, during a period of credit stress for the issuer, except if that
support is systemwide. Neither does the SACP include the potential for the
owner or government under a stress to extract assets, capital, or liquidity
from the issuer.
11. We assign the SACP at the issuer level. It is not generally applied to
specific obligations, except in some cases when an issuer does not have
an ICR. But the SACP can directly influence ratings on deferrable
instruments (hybrids). While we use the ICR as the starting point for rating
nondeferrable debt, we use the SACP as the basis for rating hybrids when
we believe that the potential for extraordinary support does not fully
extend to them or that extraordinary interference may even target them
specifically.
12. We conceive SACPs as existing on a scale ranging from 'aaa' to 'd',
which parallels the ICR rating scale, 'AAA' to 'D'. We use 'd' or 'sd' SACPs for
issuers with 'D' or 'SD' ICRs respectively. S&P Global Ratings' uses
lowercase letters for SACPs to indicate their status as a component of a
rating rather than as a rating. While we attempt to refine the SACP and
utilize "+" and "-" to graduate the scale in the same way we do for ICRs, in
some cases we may use category-only scoring. Text accompanying the
SACP will discuss whether the score is a category or is refined.
13. We recognize it is not always possible to assign an SACP, particularly
when the issuer's operations and finances are closely intertwined with the
related group or governmental entity's position.3/29/25, 7:49 PM S&P Global Ratings
https://disclosure.spglobal.com/ratings/en/regulatory/article/-/view/sourceId/6219375 3/13
The SACP Includes Ongoing Interaction/Influence
14. The determination of an SACP includes ongoing interaction or
influence, whether beneficial (positive), neutral, or burdensome (negative).
We also include extraordinary support when we believe it has been
committed. Ongoing interaction or influence from governments includes
interaction with an entire sector on a continuous basis. We consider that
groups, including owners and affiliates, influence the SACP when there are
regular interactions with the issuer. Table 1 presents examples of
influences that we would include in determining the SACP.

The SACP Does Not Include Potential Extraordinary
Intervention
15. We include potential future extraordinary intervention in the ICR
determination, but not in the SACP.
16. We consider interventions as "extraordinary" when they are issuer-
specific, related to the issuer's financial stress, and nonrecurrent in
nature. Such intervention could be in the form of support to the issuer
from groups or governments or interference with the issuer from groups or
governments--for example to protect such groups' or governments' own
credit quality--that weaken an issuer.
17. Based on our assessment of the relationship between the issuer and
its government or group, we form an opinion on the likelihood of timely and
sufficient extraordinary intervention in support of the issuer meeting its
financial obligations. While support can take many forms, common types
include capital and liquidity injections or risk relief (table 2).
18. In our analysis, we specify the potential sources of future extraordinary
external intervention. The relevant parent may or may not be the ultimate
parent, particularly when intermediate holding companies may exist
between the issuer and the relevant parent; government intervention with
an issuer may come from national or local public authorities; and an ICR
may be influenced by several parents (in the case of non-fully owned
subsidiaries), affiliates, and/or governments.
19. If we expect an issue or issuer to receive extraordinary support in the
very near term to prevent it from defaulting, we will assign an SACP of 'cc'.3/29/25, 7:49 PM S&P Global Ratings
